spoken_words: Don't worry, Bart, we'll find something fun for you to do.
Ah! Here we are! Here's a whole box of unsealed envelopes for the PTA.
Oh, licking envelopes can be fun! All you have to do is make a game of it.
Well... for example... you could see how many you can lick in an hour, and then try to break that record.
You didn't believe me when I said it would be fun, did you?
Hmm... Well there's still a minute to go... oh, why not! But don't you tell your teacher I let you go home early.
I don't have an appointment with any large men --
I'm PRINCIPAL Skinner, yes. And how, may I ask, did you get past the hall monitors?
I suppose you're all wondering where I've been. It all started a week ago. I was at my desk, revising and updating the school dress codes, when...
I was suddenly confronted by a gang of toughs acting on behalf of one Bart Simpson. Or so they said.
To get my mind off that ugly confrontation I went home and began bundling my old newspapers. But suddenly the pile fell. I was trapped. Let this be a lesson to recycle frequently.

For the next week I stayed alive by eating my mother's delicious preserves and maintained my sanity by dribbling a nearby basketball with my one free hand. I made a game of it, seeing how many times I could bounce the ball in a day, then trying to break that record. Occasionally the police arrived to search my home.
I shouted until I was hoarse, but they couldn't hear me.
Finally I realized if I was ever going to get out of there, I would have to do it myself.

I formed a crude rocket from a discarded cigar tube. And remembering an experiment from my days as a fourth grade science teacher, I concocted a fuel from baking soda and the juice of discarded lemon wedges.
The rocket took off with a mighty blast of carbon dioxide, dragging behind it the end of a vacuum cleaner cord.
I grabbed on to the vacuum cleaner, pushed the cord retractor button and was on my way to freedom.
They called me old-fashioned for teaching the duck and cover. But who's laughing now?
Your attention please. This is Principal Skinner. Bart, this one's for you. Hello ma baby, hello ma honey, hello my ragtime gal... Send me a kiss by wire..
One... more... time! HELLO MA BABY... HELLO MA HONEY... HELLO MY RAGTIME GAL. DOUBLETIME, NOW. SEND ME A KISS BY WIRE...

Well, you're in for a whale of a show tonight. I'd like to point out that the doors are now locked, so you parents can't sneak out of the show after your own child has performed. Oh, and let me caution the people in the first five rows, you will get wet.
Oh well, make sure you return those chairs to the cafeteria, Kim. I'm not kidding.
Terrible, just terrible. You know, they seem to get worse every year.
Wonderful. You know, I think this is the best batch we've ever had. I really do. And now, here's Bart Simpson, The Boy of a Thousand Voices.
That young man just became the Boy of a Thousand Days Detention.
This act is over! Well, ladies and gentlemen, I'd like to put this filth behind us, and let's all enjoy Lisa Simpson's rendition of "Stormy Leather -- ah, Weather."
Let's hear it for Lisa Simpson and her wacky sax.
Now, boys and girls, let's welcome our special guest, Ted Carpenter from the Twirl King yo-yo company.
People... people... Allllll right. You know I can wait just as long as you. Knock it off!
No. Mmm... careful now...ooh... gee that one grazed my ear...
I saw some awful things in 'Nam, but you really have to wonder at the mentality that would desecrate a helpless puma. I never thought I'd say this, but the no-goodniks rule this school!
Bart Simpson on the side of law and order? Has the world gone topsy-turvy?
Bart, there are a lot of troublemakers in this school... and Lord knows I can't be everywhere at once.
Look, let's can the euphemisms, huh? No more bullspit. How would you like to be a hall monitor?
I have never seen a good student take such a slide. Lisa, what are you rebelling against?
Bart, you're doing a bang-up job. You know, before there were some corridors of this school you'd just never go down. Now I feel safe anywhere.
Bart, the school is a police state. Students are afraid to sneeze. And I have you to thank. Come with me.
Yes Bart, whenever a teacher confiscates something it ends up here. Salacious halter-tops, complete collections of Mad, Cracked and the occasional issue of Crazy, and this fake plastic derriere.
Now, to show my gratitude, I want you to help yourself to an item of your choice.
Oh, Things have changed. There will be no mockery of your name, Mr. Glasscock.
Ladies and gentlemen, the unthinkable has happened. Some sick, twisted individual has stolen every teacher's edition in this school.
Bart, the police haven't had any luck finding the teachers' editions.
Oh, Bart, I'm not sure random locker searches are permitted by the Supreme Court...
Oh, answers! Answers! Simpson, you've just saved the school one hundred and twenty dollars. Who's behind this monstrous crime?
I've been so blind. In retrospect, the signs all pointed to a rogue hall monitor.
D'oh. Now Bart, in light of your recent service to the school, I've decided to be lenient. Four hundred days detention.
Just think what we can buy with that money. History books that know how the Korean War came out. Math books that don't have that Base six crap in them.
And a state of the art detention hall, where children are held in place with magnets.
One eraser? Oh, I'm used to my government betraying me. I was in Nam. I served for three --
Well, that tears it. Until you get a license and wear your own underwear, mister, you are suspended without pay.
I drove an all-terrain vehicle in Da Nang. I think I can handle it.
Otto. That's one palindrome you won't be hearing for awhile.
HE DRINKS AND HE CUSSES / HE STINKS UP THE BUSSES/HAIL TO THE BUS DRIVER, BUS DRIVER MAN! HA HA!
Dum de dum... There's an opening. Too late!... Nope... Nope... That'd be cutting it a little close.
Nonsense. One of our good citizens will slow down and wave me in.
Samantha I've always been suspicious of transfer students... Other principals try to unload problem cases that way... Lord knows I do.

Yeah sure, and they told me I'd get a big parade when I got back from 'Nam. Instead they spat on me. I can still feel it searing. So, now let's just see what the permanent record has to say, shall we?
Hmm... no detention... fairly good attendance record... Oh, I see you beat that bed wetting problem in the second grade.
Don't worry. They'll forget. Just like they forgot about me in that tiger cage for eighteen agonizing months. Every night I'd wake up screaming. Well, let's meet your classmates.
I think we should discuss this later, Edna. Now, it's never easy to come to a new school, so let's make her feel right at home. Please say a big elementary school hello to Samantha Stinky.
Attention, everyone. This is Principal Skinner. I trust you all remembered to bring in your implements of destruction.
Somebody put a torch to these permanent records! Quickly now.
Attention students: please clear out your lockers into the waste baskets provided.
Hmmm, I haven't seen such unfettered hurly-burly since the fall of Saigon. Well, William, another school year gone by.
Well, back to work then. Make sure to give those toilets a good scrubbing. We want the old girls sparkling when I get back.
Well, so did you. You got an ex-Green Beret mad.
Now in a moment, we'll be raffling off our grand prize...
But first, our second-prize winner, and the recipient of this handsome shoe buffer....... Ned Flanders!
And the winner of the blimp ride is... Homer Simpson!
Uh, you've been flushing for twenty minutes. Is there a problem?
We won't miss a minute of school, thanks to your father.
Bart, we'll do anything you want. Just call off your giant mechanical ants!
Lisa, I know I can trust you to inventory this Glee Club peanut brittle.
Now, I've gotta slash 40 percent out of the budget.
Listen to your mother, Lisa. I owe everything I have to my mother's watchful eye... and swift hand.
Oh, there's mother now. Watching me. What's that, mother? They have a right to be here. It's school business. I... Mother, that sailor suit doesn't fit anymore!
Some student -- possibly Bart Simpson -- has been circulating candy hearts featuring crude, off-color sentiments. Well let me tell you something, Valentine's Day is no joke...
This orange drink is the only way to recoup our terrible losses from "Fire Drill Follies." I just don't know what went wrong.
Hmm. So mother was right -- it was my fault. Go ahead, water it down some more.
Good evening, everyone, and welcome to a wonderful evening of theater and picking up after yourselves.
... with a thorough re-telling of the life of George Washington.
Well Edna, for a school with no Asian kids, I think we put on a pretty darn good science fair.
Over, under, in and out, that's what shoe tying's all about.
Lisa, every good scientist is half B.F. Skinner, and half P.T. Barnum. I don't think I need to see the other exhibits. First prize!
Batten down those cowlicks... straighten that part... uncross those eyes, Mister.
Children, we've just been tipped off that Superintendent Chalmers is planning a surprise inspection. So let's clean up this pigsty!
On another topic, the following students have won mountain bikes: Bart Simpson...
You may pick the bikes up in Utility Basement B.
Sorry about the ruse, gentlemen. You're being swept under the rug for the Superintendent's visit. Enjoy!
Would the world judge me harshly if I threw away the key?
So what's the word down at One School Board Plaza?
They were the children's idea. I tried to stop them.
May I interest you in a Jello brick, Sir? There's a grape in the center.
You're not made of stone... a brick and you're... made of stone...
Well let's pick one at random. How about that one?
No he said what's that rattle. It's about the heating duct.
Well, you know what they say, sir. "Where there's no smoke, there's no fire."
There's no detention this time, Simpson. This is the end. You are expelled from Springfield Elementary!
Bart, I'm very impressed at the independent learning you've displayed here.
Yes. Anyway, as a reward for your studying, I've decided to welcome you back to our school. You'll be reunited with your chums, Nelson, Jimbo, Dol... Oh dear God!
Then we ride these bikes to Mexico -- and freedom, Willie! Freedom!
Mother, get an extra-special hug ready. I've bought you a new juicer!
Good Lord! Flu germs entering every orifice in my head.
"Prisoner 24601"... Why, I wore this for two years in a Viet Cong internment center. Never thought I'd see the old girl again.
Only one question remains gentlemen. What do we call ourselves?
We need a name that's witty at first, but that seems less funny each time you hear it.
Oh, he's with his new girlfriend. The Japanese conceptual artist.
Gentlemen, US Magazine just came out with its "What's Hot and What's Not Issue."
Well William, I'm back. So, how did you spend your summer?
I can't remember the last time we were all together.
Hey, everybody. Let's go sing at the hospital! FOR WE'VE GOT...
Hello, Simpson. I'm riding the bus today because Mother hid my car keys to punish me for talking to a woman on the phone. She was right to do it.
Now I've gotten word that a child is using his imagination, and I've come to put a stop to it.
The only monster on this bus is a lack of proper respect for the rules.
Right or wrong, your behavior was still disruptive, young man. Perhaps spending the remainder of your life in a madhouse will teach you some manners.
I'm annoyed with you, Mother. Not just annoyed... Angry! I'm a grown man now! And I can run MY OWN LIFE!!
What is it with you kids and that word? I'm going to shave you bald, young man, until you learn that hair is not a right, it's a privilege.
Now, I uh hesitate to bring this up, but a number of cities have rejuvenated their economies with uh, legalized gambling.
Uh, there is an added bonus -- some of the revenue can go to help our under-funded public schools!
And special awards go to the two students who obviously had no help from their parents, Lisa Simpson and Ralph Wiggum.
Thank you, Edna, everyone. Now class... I wonder who among you can tell me what this is?
Class, instead of going to the box factory, today we'll be going to the... box factory.
I'll handle this. Simpson! I'm giving you 'til the count of three to come out. One... two... three. I've done all I can do.
Now wait just a minute. That wasn't discussed with me.
Uh, excuse me, is there an Orange Julius stand on this floor?
Well why don't I drink out of a toilet bowl?
I know Weinstein's parents were upset, Superintendent, but, but ah, I was sure it was a phony excuse. I mean, it sounds so made up: "Yom Kip-pur?"
Children, teachers, back to your rooms! Uh-oh, whenever I get this upset, I get hiccups. Ooh, right on cue.
Superintendent Chalmers, you didn't have to come all the way down here. Everything's under control.
Now, really I hardly think the children's appearance should --

Well, maybe it was for the best. Now I... I finally have time to do what I've always wanted: write the Great American Novel. Mine is about a futuristic amusement park where dinosaurs are brought to life through advanced cloning techniques!
Well, let's see. Tide, Cheer, Bold, Biz, Fab, All, Gain, Wisk. I believe today I will try... Bold.
It was? Well, then we should get together again! Uh, say Saturday, at my house. Do you know where I live?
Hmmm, a flaming bag, eh? Well, these new Italian loafers will make short work of it.
That's not true. I can buy a new pair. No, I can't. I needed those. I really did.
Bum-ba-bum-bum! Ba-ba-ba-bum! Now a little more allegro than last time. Bart! Welcome! Can I offer you a Diet Caffeine-Free Dr. Pepper or an individual fruit cocktail cup?
Oh, that's my old unit from Vietnam. I was their Sergeant, they were my loyal troops.
That photo was taken shortly before I was shot in the back ... Which was very strange, because it was during a Bob Hope show. I was trying to get Joey Heatherton to put on some pants for God's sake.
Ned Flanders actually eliminated detention and put the whole school on the honor system?
Oh, that place must be falling apart. Oh, mercy. Nobody's mentioned me, have they?
I thought you might like this restaurant, Bart. They'll make a pizza pie with the topping of your choice.
No, no, Luigi, I'd like one with two seats. I'll be dining with a friend tonight.

"Dear Bart, your friendship during this difficult time will not be forgotten. However, I've decided to return to the only thing besides school that has ever given my life meaning -- I've re-enlisted in the United States Army. Sincerely, Sgt. Seymour Skinner."
Hmm. Yes, Colonel. Now, I understand it will be my duty to mold the new recruits into a well-disciplined, highly-trained infantry unit.
Wait, wait, wait, wait. Where did you pick up that filth?!
Yes, well, there will be no smut in my company. You're in this man's army to learn!
Uh, I must admit, I do miss the school. And uh, frankly, the Army isn't quite as I remembered it.
Actually, it's exactly as I remembered it. I do want to come back, Bart, but it doesn't sound like Flanders is gonna get fired.
...Yes. Now you realize, if I become Principal again, we can no longer be friends. Unless you become a good student.
Yeah, well one question remains. How do I get out of the army?
Dirksen, tuck in your shirt. Jaffee, spit out that gum.
"Please excuse my handwriting. I busted whichever hand it is I write with. Signed, Mrs. Simpson." You were right to be suspicious, Edna. To the crime lab.
I wish more students had agreed to these electronic tracking implants. We only had one volunteer.
We did not! Now where's Bart? You better tell me!
If I were a truant boy out for a good time I'd be right here. The Springfield Natural History Museum.
Why, there are no children here at the Four 'H' Club either! Am I so out of touch? No. It's the children who are wrong.
Hmm. His brand of gum--Doublemint. Trying to double your fun, eh, Bart? Well, I'll double your detention. I wish someone was around to hear that. And so we enter end game.
Bart Simpson, I know you cut school yesterday. And as soon as I can prove it, I'm shipping you off to the Christian Military Reform School.
I know you can read my thoughts, Bart. Just a little reminder: if I find out you cut class, your ass is mine. Yes, you heard me. I think words I would never say.
I can't wait 'til the sentencing part. That's where I really shine.
Bart Simpson, for the heinous crime of hooky, I sentence you to a lifetime of hard labor in the cafeteria.
If the jury is deadlocked, they're put up in a hotel together so they can't communicate with the outside world.
A conjunction meaning "in the event that" or "on condition that."
Justice is not a frivolous thing, Simpson. It has little, if anything, to do with a disobedient whale. Now let's vote.
You know, we're kind of like the original "Odd Couple." You're the messy one and I'm...
I knew it! I knew you'd slip up sooner or later, Simpson.
Bart, I'm impressed with what you did in there. You testified for the Quimby boy even though it was putting your own head in a noose. On the other hand, you skipped school.
I'm a small man in some ways, Bart. A small, petty man. Three months detention.
I hardly think it's fair to be charged full price. I'm up to my knees in the original cast of M*A*S*H.
Uh, well, as a matter of fact, my refrigerator wasn't running. You spared me quite a bit of spoilage. Thank you, anonymous young man.
Door to door sugar? What a marvelous idea! What's that, mother? I'm just talking to the sugar man. Mother, I'm a big boy. I can do as I wish. Excuse me.
Ah, Diorama-rama. My favorite school event next to Hearing Test Thursday.
Yes, yes. Very good wrath. Ah, let's see, our foreign exchange student, Uter, has chosen "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". Eh... But this is just an empty box!
Bart, stop creating a diversion and get out of here!
Mm, I can't wait to see this. Be ready with the ribbon.
Allison, is this supposed to be some kind of joke?!
Oh is that so, young lady? Well, where is this phantom diorama?
Ah, at least have the guts to take the blame, girl. You're only compounding your folly by lying about it.

Young lady, cow hearts belong in a butcher's window, not the classroom. Well, maybe in an older student's biology classroom, but that's none of my business. Elementary school is where I wound up and it's too late to do anything about that. Frankly, I'm starting to regret skipping you ahead.
Oh, well, that changes everything. Let's have a look. Get the ribbon ready.
Oh. A little sterile... no real insight. What do you think, Miss Hoover?
This has been a very disappointing day. All right, on to Lisa Simpson.
Oh noW, we're into the dregs. Here's Ralph Wiggum's entry.
Prepackaged "Star Wars" characters still in their display box?! Are those the limited edition action figures?
Why, it's Luke, and Obie-Wan... and my favorite, Chewie. They're all here! What do you think?
Now, as a special send-off and a way to say "Gung hay fat choy" to our visiting Chinese principals, Bart Simpson has promised us a fireworks display!

Now, students, I want you to be on your best behavior for this carefully-choreographed media event. Now this means there is to be no wising-off, no face-making, and no grass-eating. This means you, Ralph.
Bart, by special request of the Mayor's office, you are going to be left back.
Well, yes... but, not for four or five years. Bart, you're going to kindergarten.
Over here, Simpson! The detention room is dangerously overcrowded, so you'll be serving your time in the cafeteria.
Yes, you should have thought of that before you made that paper airplane.
This overcrowding in detention is becoming critical. It's a powder keg waiting to go off in an explosion of unacceptable behavior.
Wouldn't it be wonderful if there were some sort of common solution to both our problems?
Hmmm. Uh, Jimbo, why don't you "assist" Lunchlady Doris in the kitchen.
Hmmm. Well, perhaps I ought to let you folks in on a secret. Do you remember me telling Jimbo Jones that I'd make something of him one day?
Now, that's your third helping, young man. It's making you fat and soft... and tender. Hmmm... Uh, you just cut in line, didn't you? Report to detention, Uter.

Oh relax, kids. I've got a gut feeling Uter's around here somewhere. After all, isn't there a little Uter in all of us? In fact, you might even say we just ate Uter and he's in our stomachs right now. Wait. Scratch that.
Easy there, young man. You'll only make yourself tired and stringy.
I'm going to enjoy devouring you, Bart Simpson. Yes... I believe I'll start, as you've so often suggested, by eating your shorts.
Congratulations, Simpson. You just fell for our sting and won yourself three months detention. There's no such thing as Scotchtoberfest.

Attention. This is Principal Skinner, your principal, with a message from the principal's office. All students please proceed immediately to an assembly in the Butthead Memorial Auditorium. Dammit I wish we hadn't let the students name that one.

Children, the times, they are a-becoming quite different. Test scores are at an all time low. So I've come up with these "Academic Alerts." You will receive one as soon as your grades start to slip in any subject. This way, your parents won't have to wait until report card time to punish you.
Muntz, Nelson. You're failing history, geography, and math. But ah, you're doing quite well in Home-Ec.
Huh, this has nothing to do with you, Simpson. I have many, many issues with my beloved smother -- mother.
The Grand Exalted Leader requests a moment of your time. Class dismissed.
And now, to top off our most propane-explosion-free Science Week ever, our grand finale! The launching of a weather balloon.
Hurrah for science, woo? I can't say I approve of the woo, but the hurrah was quite heartening. Release the balloon.
Whoever brings down that balloon doesn't have to learn fractions!
It won't come down for months. Curse the man who invented helium. Curse Pierre Jules Cesar Janssen! Now to find out who did this.
Hmmm... blueprints of the dummy, ... notarized photos of you making the dummy... and an alternate wording for the banner: "Buttzilla."
I am going to punish you for this, Bart. And it won't just be a simple caning this time.

Because you have impeded science, you must now aid science. Yes. Starting tomorrow, you will assist me with my amateur astronomy. Taking down coordinates, carrying equipment and so forth. Four-thirty in the morning.
Ah, there's nothing more exciting than science. You get all the fun of sitting still, being quiet, writing down numbers, paying attention... Science has it all!
Yes, but you won't be looking through it. I forbid it. But you don't need a telescope to enjoy astronomy, Bart. There are all the constellations you've heard so much about.
Well, you do have to use your imagination. Look, there's the Three Wise Men.
Whoever discovers them. I've been hoping I could find something that would be named after me.

Once. But by the time I got to a phone, my discovery had already been reported by Principal Kohoutek. I got back at him though. Him and that little boy of his. Anyway... that's why I always keep a cellular phone next to me. Now, this morning we're gonna be mapping a small square of sky that's thought to be empty. It's my hope that it's not.
Just write down my findings as I give them to you. Six hours, nineteen minutes, right ascension, fourteen degrees, twenty-two minutes declination... No sighting.
Six hours, nineteen minutes, right ascension, fourteen degrees, twenty-three minutes declination... No sighting.
Six hours, nineteen minutes right ascension, fourteen degrees fifty-eight minutes declination... No sighting. Did you get that one, Bart?
No, no there's no need for that... it's already named after me.
It's coming pretty close to the ground. Maybe I can catch it. Don't touch the telescope, Bart. Even a slight change in elevation can destroy a whole morning's work.
I've got it! What are you doing? Give me that phone.

Attention students. It's time once again to choose a gym class for the coming term. So let's all prove how adult we can be by filing to the gym in a calm and orderly manner. Even though it's first-come first-serve, and the most popular sports fill up fast.
There is only one class left, but it happens to be the "coolest" one of all.
You're gonna have to work hard to win this crowd over. Most of them are here as part of detention.
Mm hm. We even bussed in troublemakers from other schools.
I'm telling you people the earth revolves around the sun.
We've been invited to the wedding of our only graduate to read at an adult level.
It'd be nice to have some companionship when mother goes out on dates.
Edna, you know they just cut the school's budget. Besides, if I had the money, I'd fix the exhaust leak in the back. Frankly, I think it's causing some of our low test scores.
All right, the battlefield is just a half mile ahead. Begin braking procedure!
Otto, why don't you get some more gas. Here's the 'credit card.'
Bu..but we don't have that kind of money. In fact, no school could afford to...
He thinks he's so hot ever since he swept the "princi" awards. Those things are rigged.
Posh. Shredded newspapers add much needed roughage and essential inks. Besides, you didn't notice the old gym mats.
Oh, c'mon, Edna. We both know these children have no future.
Well, the kids have to learn about Tek War sooner or later.
We'll see about that. Simpson, I always thought you were sneaky and manipulative, but now I see you're really a very sensitive little boy.
Attention. This is an emergency broadcast. All is well in the school. My authority as principal is total -- Hey, gimme that.
Yeah, in a dream world. We have a very tight budget. To do what she's asking, we'd have to raise taxes.
Well children, I don't know what you did to all those substitutes, but it's going to stop now. Leopold?
Me? Go to my office? It's highly irregular, but all right...
Let us out, Bart! / This is not funny, come on! / Bart, let us out right now!
Come on! Or you are going to be very, very sorry.
What's the point? There's no more money. Unless you've got some magic new source of revenue.
This was a great way to make extra money. Renting out our cloakrooms to the overcrowded prison system.
And as a bonus some of our more troublesome students might be scared straight.
Superintendant Chalmers, I'd like you to meet our new school nurse, Lunchlady Doris.
Well, in many cases the floor is the best... oh look! Here comes Lumpy, the school snake!
Now I have learned that most of the orchestra is having their appendixes removed. So without further ado, I give you the remnants of the Springfield Elementary School Orchestra.
They will be playing Stars and Stripes Forever -- hopefully not forever.
I didn't burn down the school. It was the butterfly, I tell you! The butterfly!

Yes, indeed there is. There's an inflatable bath pillow that mother and I both enjoy. She claimed it was her day to use it. I maintain she was mistaken. We quarreled. Later, as I prepared to bathe, I noticed to my horror, that "someone" had slashed the pillow.
Well, I could send it back to Taiwan for repair, but why should I have to? I've done nothing wrong. And I don't give permission for my face to be on TV. I want it blurred.
Ah, is there nothing so intoxicating as the school hallway at early morn?
Ahh. Washbasin fresh. That funk must be coming from one of the classrooms.
Willie, sometime over the holiday weekend, the beloved Grade Four gerbil, er, Superdude, lost his life. I need you to air out the classroom and give Superdude a proper burial.
Yes. Now, to re-direct our conversation slightly, I had a few ideas on how to spend this oil money.
Oh mercy. Seriously though, before we draw up the budget, I believe the students and faculty have a few suggestions...
That's odd. I don't have a secretary, or an intercom. But send him in.
It was naive of you to think I would mistake this town's most prominent 104 year-old man for one of my elementary school students.
That hotel's a dump, and your monopoly is pathetic. The school's oil well is not for sale. Particularly to a black-hearted scoundrel like yourself!

Today, Springfield Elementary embarks on a new era: an era of unbridled spending where petro-dollars will fuel our wildest educational fantasies. These young minds will enjoy every academic advantage... ...until they enter Springfield High School, which has no oil well.
Fine. Now, to switch on our oil pump for the very first time, here's our top student, Lisa Simpson.
I'm afraid we've got no legal recourse against Mr. Burns and his slant- drilling operation. The oil belongs to whoever pumped it first.
In fact, to pay for the construction, and operation, and demolition of our new derrick, the school will have to eliminate all non-essential programs: music...
Now, I did - I did go to the town meeting with the intention of ambushing Mr. Burns. When it adjourned, I rushed to the lavatory to apply my camouflage makeup...
Oh yes. But, anything else he tells you is a filthy lie.
Students, I have an announcement. One of your favorite comic book heroes, Radio Man...
Strange. I shouldn't have been able to hear that. Anyway, a Hollywood studio has decided to film the Radioactive Man movie here in Springfield.
And they will be holding auditions to find a local youngster to play Fallout Boy.
Oh, and the air conditioner will be fixed this afternoon.
What kind of parents would permit such a lapse in scalpel hygiene?
Lisa Simpson, report to the principal's office for head lice inspection.
Sweet Georgia Brown! Something is rotten at the Simpson house.
Uh-oh. Two independent thought alarms in one day. The students are over stimulated. Willie, remove all the colored chalk from the classrooms.

Good morning class. A certain agitator -- for privacy's sake let's call her Lisa S. -- No, that's too obvious. Uh, let's say L. Simpson -- has raised questions about certain school policies. So in the interest of creating an open dialogue, sit silently and watch this film.
Now as a special treat courtesy of our friends at the Meat Council, please help yourselves to this tripe.
Children, I couldn't help monitoring your conversation. There's no mystery about Willie. Why, he simply disappeared... Now, let's have no more curiosity about this bizarre cover-up.
Wheel him out quietly. It's best the children don't see him.
...Recharge fire extinguishers. This is a free service of the fire department.
As I was saying, my yearly evaluation couldn't've come at a better time.

The year was 1968. We were on re-con in a steaming Mekong delta. An overheated private removed his flak jacket, revealing a T-shirt with an iron-on sporting the Mad slogan, "UP WITH MINI-SKIRTS." Well, we all had a good laugh, even though I didn't quite understand it.
